repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Eastern Anatolia Watershed
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is rated
            satisfactory on balance, mainly due to the substantially
            environmental focus of the objectives and the good
            achievements in planting of forest lands and intensifying
            agriculture. Bank performance was, on balance, satisfactory,
            but there were some areas of weakness in strategy and policy
            and the Bank could have pushed further, even at mid-term,
            towards challenging the community decision processes in the
            direction of identifying and targeting the poor and
            involving women. Legal rangeland ownership issues and
            associated data were clearly not adequately understood at
            appraisal. Borrower performance is rated satisfactory but
            there were some weaknesses. The borrower was committed to
            the project and provided very strong leadership in achieving
            the inter-departmental coordination between the Department
            of Reforestation and Erosion Control (AGM) within MOF, the
            General Directorate of Production and Development (TUGEM),
            the General Directorate for Agricultural Research (TAGEM),
            and the General Directorate of Rural Services (KHGM) within
            the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs (MARA). The
            sustainability is rated non-evaluable, based on a weighting
            of several elements. The objectives of the project as stated
            were, essentially, "to restore sustainable (land
            management) in the upper watersheds". There are a
            number of concerns about sustainability but also, given the
            very long-term impact of these objectives and the lack of
            early impact data, unusually large uncertainties.

abstracts.cdata!:
More than 70 percent of Turkey's
            land area faces soil degradation from erosion, resulting in
            low productivity and low rural incomes. In 1993, the World
            Bank approved the Eastern Anatolia Watershed Rehabilitation
            project, which has since improved the lives of farmers in
            more than 300 mountain villages, by enabling them to grow
            new cash crops and by teaching them new farming techniques
            that have boosted agricultural production dramatically. The
            project was designed to increase the productivity of forest
            land, promote the sustainable use of marginal farmland, and
            increase the involvement of local communities in planning
            and managing their own natural resources. Smaller projects
            have been carried out in 11 provinces, covering 617,000
            hectares and benefiting 227,000 people. Since its launch,
            rural incomes have at least doubled, and satellite images
            reveal a marked difference in vegetation, which will help
            reduce floods and sedimentation.

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Eastern Anatolia Watershed
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts substantial. Major lessons are as
            follows. A participatory project design should focus on the
            process, rather than on physical targets, although clearly,
            informed assumptions have to be made for the purpose of
            estimating costs, and returns. In this case, the design
            should have allowed for an annual cycle of work, starting
            from participatory micro catchment planning, while the ratio
            between conservation, and supporting income-generating
            expenditure should be further addressed. While the project
            delivered an infrequent, and invaluable lesson in the
            successful collaboration between implementing agencies, it
            also showed that key elements within such cooperation (and
            that of villagers) are time, and training, requiring
            flexibility to accommodate each agency's contribution
            to its fullest extent. Despite successes, legal
            uncertainties surrounded the rangeland, particularly the
            non-forest rangeland, aggravated by an inadequate legal
            framework for the Ministry of Agriculture's
            participation in related activities. Nonetheless, the
            exemplary approach taken by project design, and
            implementation is worth noting, which built on existing
            local technology, and capacity, thus enhancing the
            employment of its farmer-centered problem-census
            problem-solving approach, in a sensitive manner. Further
            lessons reinforce the need for social, and extension skills
            provision, stakeholder participation, training appropriately
            timed, monitoring and evaluation performance criteria, as
            well as the provision of technical expertise.

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - In-Situ Conservation of Genetic
            Diversity Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was highly
            satisfactory. In-situ conservation areas for woody and
            non-woody target species were established, and institutional
            capacity for the development of a national strategy plan for
            in-situ conservation, was built. Despite successful
            achievements, project implementation was longer than
            expected, and, the one year extension of closing date, was
            due to biological and scientific reasons, which caused
            delays in the selection of gene management zones (GMZs). The
            lessons learned suggest that, a number of elements should be
            in place for successful in-situ conservation efforts,
            mainly, that forestry, agriculture, and environmental
            agencies actively coordinate these efforts, and
            specifically, that communities in the proximity of the GMZs,
            be properly familiarized, and participate in project
            management. Effective mechanisms, such as the Project
            Implementation Committee or Inter-Ministerial Steering
            Committee could cooperate, if limited experience exists
            among project agencies in working together; and, project
            design should include funding to secure community
            participation. Projects which are technical in nature,
            require adequate training in the most advanced techniques,
            same should be provided at the earliest stages. Finally,
            task teams' continuity is paramount to maintain mutual
            trust and understanding to attain success.

5082256.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - In-situ Conservation of Genetic
            Diversity Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This subproject would seek to identify
            and establish in-situ conservation areas in Turkey, for the
            protection of genetic resources and wild relatives of
            important crops and forest tree species that originated in
            Turkey. It will provide for sustainable in-situ conservation
            of genetic resources in cereals, horticultural crops,
            medicinal plants, forest trees, and pasture grasses and
            legumes through an integrated ecosystem approach. It will
            also contribute to the broader objective of conserving
            sustainable farming and forest systems that is a key element
            of the Watershed Rehabilitation project. The project will
            develop the institutional capacity in Turkey for preparing
            and implementing a national strategy for in-situ
            conservation which could include landraces in a second phase
            project, for which support from the GET will be sought. The
            aim is to test and develop a new approach to conservation of
            genetic diversity which has not been tried on a large scale
            anywhere in the world.

0.cdata!: Global Environment Facility Trust Fund Grant

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Eastern Anatolia Watershed
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This subproject would seek to identify
            and establish in-situ conservation areas in Turkey, for the
            protection of genetic resources and wild relatives of
            important crops and forest tree species that originated in
            Turkey. It will provide for sustainable in-situ conservation
            of genetic resources in cereals, horticultural crops,
            medicinal plants, forest trees, and pasture grasses and
            legumes through an integrated ecosystem approach. It will
            also contribute to the broader objective of conserving
            sustainable farming and forest systems that is a key element
            of the Watershed Rehabilitation project. The project will
            develop the institutional capacity in Turkey for preparing
            and implementing a national strategy for in-situ
            conservation which could include landraces in a second phase
            project, for which support from the GET will be sought. The
            aim is to test and develop a new approach to conservation of
            genetic diversity which has not been tried on a large scale
            anywhere in the world.

docna.cdata!:
Turkey - Eastern Anatolia Watershed
            Rehabilitation Project

display_title.display_title:
Turkey - Eastern Anatolia
            Watershed Rehabilitation Project
